columns.text: In this exercise, we are to determine whether or not the sales growth is consistent with the constraints provided in the problem.

## Accounting Return on Equity
\
Accounting Return on Equity is referred to as the financial measure of the company's financial performance. The ROE is computed by dividing the net income of the company by the total equity.

## Debt-to-Equity Ratio
\
The debt-to-equity ratio is referred to as the ratio of the liabilities and equity that is used to finance the operations of the company.
\
The debt-to-equity ratio is computed as follows:
 
$$\text{Debt-to-Equity Ratio}=\frac{\text{Total Liabilities}}{\text{Total Equity}}$$

## Profit Margin
\
Profit margin is the ratio to which the company generates profit from its revenue.
\
Profit margin is considered as a determinant of growth since an increase in this ratio will consequently increase the company's ability to generate profit that is used to fund the internal operations of the firm, thus increasing the sustainable growth of the company.
\
The profit margin is computed as follows:
 
$$\text{Profit Margin}=\frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Sales}}$$

## Capital Intensity Ratio
\
The capital intensity ratio is referred to as the ratio of the assets that generate the sales of the operations of the company.
\
The capital intensity ratio is computed as follows:
 
$$\text{Capital Intensity Ratio}=\frac{\text{Total Assets}}{\text{Sales}}$$

First, let us determine the accounting rate of return using the following given:
 

<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Debt-to-Equity Ratio|0.43|
|Profit Margin|5.9\%|
|Capital Intensity Ratio|1.80|

To compute the accounting return on equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned}\text{Return on Equity}&=\text{Profit Margin}\times\frac{1}{\text{Capital Intensity Ratio}}\\[10pt]
&\times(1+\text{Debt-to-Equity Ratio})\\[12pt]
&=\text{5.9\%}\times\frac{1}{\text{1.80}}\times(1+\text{0.43})\\[12pt]
&=\text{5.9\%}\times0.56\times1.43\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{0.0472}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The return on equity is 0.0472.**

## Retention Ratio
\
The retention ratio is referred to as the rate of the net income that is included in the retained earnings and is used to grow the business.

Now, let us compute the retention ratio:
 
<center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Growth Rate|12\%|
 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Retention Ratio}&=\frac{\text{Growth Rate}}{\text{ROE+(ROE}\times\text{Growth Rate)}}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{\text{12\%}}{\text{0.0472+(0.0472}\times\text{12\%)}}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{\text{12\%}}{\text{0.0472+0.0057}}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{\text{12\%}}{\text{0.0529}}\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{2.27}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The retention ratio is 2.27.**

Now, let us determine the dividend payout ratio:
$$\begin{aligned}\\
\text{Dividend Payout Ratio}&=1-\text{Retention Ratio}\\[12pt]
&=1-2.27\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{(1.27)}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The dividend payout ratio is 1.27.**

Based on the computations in the determination of the dividend payout ratio arriving at 1.27, the computed amount is considered to be impossible since the dividend payout ratio should only be less than or equal to 1 since this ratio indicates the amount of the dividends in the net sales of the company.
\
Therefore, it is determined that the lowest possible payout ratio is 0 having the retention ratio of 1, and vice versa.
